text: So you're assuming that every six year old gamer is a moron who would miss an optional tutorial or not read a manual?  Nice hyperbole there, slick.  I'm pretty positive that younger gamers growing up in the SNES/PS1 eras had an okay time with optional tutorials in video games.  Consider having a small fraction of a clue when you type.

text: I highly doubt a 6 year old child would suffer a brain aneurysm from having an OPTIONAL tutorial mode in a video game.  And as for Skyward Sword?  Let's see, Fi's insultingly obvious helper lines (worse than Navi), less exploration, forgettable NPC's, just to name a few.

author: GoRedskinsAndWizards

text: I first started this game in 1997; I was only able to make incremental progress over a long period. I didn't finish until 2001. Now I can beat it in a few days (not sure what the clock would come out to in game time; it doesn't keep track like the 3D Zeldas). Maybe it's just because it was my first, but this is my favorite Zelda, though I didn't play OoT until very recently; my feelings about OoT might be stronger if I'd played it when it came out.

author: Everlasting

text: You're Link, you wake up in the middle of the night during a thunderstorm, you head for Hyrule's Castle, find your mortally wounded uncle who gives you his sword and begin one of the greatest adventures of all time. No need for long, boring tutorials and walls of text, you gradually understand the game's mechanics as you go. I wish I could say we'll ever get a Zelda intro as good as this one, but I unfortunately doubt it. A Link Between Worlds, please don't disappoint!
author: SupraDarky
